On Thu, Apr 17, 2008 at 8:25 PM, Joseph Reisinger <joeraii@...> wrote:
>
>  Anyway, I'm curious to know why you believe such methods won't scale
>  or generalize well? (sorry I know that sounds like a totally loaded
>  question now, but I'm genuinely interested in hearing your opinion --
>  I've been keeping an eye on the UCT literature for a while and its
>  hard to see the world without UCT-colored glasses anymore :P)

Hey Joe...yeah, it's a loaded question, but I'll give it a shot. :)

My current perspective on how humans (and to a lesser extent other
species) are able to flexibly learn a wide range of novel cognitive
tasks has to do with their ability to encode invariant representations
of spatio-temporal patterns, and once acquired, use those encodings to
recognize, generate, and predict sequences. I think this general
perspective helps frame how people can learn to play tennis, speak
Chinese, play the piano, and master games like Go.

My understanding of UCT is that it is a method of pruning the search
tree for Monte Carlo methods, but in the end you're still talking
about a brute force search of child nodes in a tree, right? I was
wondering how MoGo dealt with simple iterative or repeating patterns
that arise in Go, like Ko fights and ladders. For those who don't
know, ladders are simple repeating structures that arise in the game
that many amateurs can instantly recognize, but which tree-search
methods perform extremely poorly at. I think the reason for this is
that a human can readily learn an invariant representation of a simple
pattern and recognize and predict the outcome regardless of
orientation or size of the board.

A quick scan of the Computer Go discussion group on the issue makes it
sound like this is a reasonably correct assessment, and that
programmers generally include some kind of ad hoc mechanism for coping
with things like ladders. This explains why MoGo can do reasonably
well when powered by a supercomputer in playing on a 9x9 board, since
structures like ladders are limited in size.

So my criticism of an algorithm like MoGo would probably boil down to
"Where is its representation of a ladder?" And if that representation
is not at all part of its core algorithm, that's where my skepticism
enters that the methodology will not scale very well, either to larger
Go boards or to other domains. I think the ability to encode and
employ invariant representations of patterns is the root of the
problem, and the whole class of MC methods seems in the spirit of
traditional AI approaches which I just don't think are going to do the
job.

--Derek
